key_points: Hurricane Ida caused significant damage to homes, infrastructure, and lives from Louisiana to New England.
It left oil slicks in the Gulf of Mexico, prompting federal and state agencies and private companies to investigate.
The U.S. Coast Guard has assessed over 1,500 reports of pollution, prioritizing nearly 350 incidents for further investigation.
Agencies involved include the Environmental Protection Agency, the state of Louisiana, and the National Ocean Service.
Landsat 8 captured images of oil slicks off Louisiana's coast near Port Fourchon, indicating potential pipeline damage.
Hurricane Ida disrupted 90 to 95 percent of the region's oil and gas production.
The surface oil slicks near Port Fourchon might originate from up to three damaged or ruptured submarine pipelines.
The extent of the oil spill into the Gulf of Mexico is uncertain.
The Gulf of Mexico's seafloor features extensive oil and gas infrastructure, raising concerns about vulnerability to storms.
The U.S. Government Accountability Office revealed that 97 percent of pipelines have been left on the seafloor when decommissioned.
